case_name: Officers of the Income-tax Department v. Union of India

facts.text: 16 Officers of the Income-tax Department filed this petition under Art. 32 praying for reliefs on grounds of infringement of Arts. 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: 16 Officers of the Income-tax Department have tiled this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution praying for various reliefs on the ground that their rights under Arts. 14 and 16 have been infringed.

facts.text: Petitioners are all confirmed Assistant Commissioners of Income tax.

anchor.surface_text: They are all companyfirmed Assistant Commissioners of the Income tax and respondents 6 to 39 are also companyfirmed Assistant Commissioners of Income tax.

facts.text: Respondents 6 to 39 are confirmed Assistant Commissioners of Income tax.

anchor.surface_text: They are all companyfirmed Assistant Commissioners of the Income tax and respondents 6 to 39 are also companyfirmed Assistant Commissioners of Income tax.

facts.text: Petitioners were all confirmed as Asstt. Commissioners in 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners were all companyfirmed as Asstt. Commissioners In 1959. Apart from respondents 28, 29 and 30, all other respondents were companyfirmed in earlier years.

facts.text: Apart from respondents 28, 29 and 30, all other respondents 6-39 were confirmed in years earlier than 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners were all companyfirmed as Asstt. Commissioners In 1959. Apart from respondents 28, 29 and 30, all other respondents were companyfirmed in earlier years.

facts.text: Petitioners claim Government breached rules and appointed respondents 6 to 39 irregularly outside quota.

anchor.surface_text: The Government in breach of the rules governing the service of Income tax officers Class 1, grade II, appointed respondents 6 to 39. Their initial, appoint- ments were irregular and illegal being outside the quota prescribed by Government for regulating recruitment to the service.

facts.text: Respondents 6-39 given preferential treatment in seniority in Class I Grade II and promotions by discriminatory rules.

anchor.surface_text: Not only were they thus illegally absorbed into service but were also L3Sup. CI./70-4 given preferential treatment in the matter of seniority in Class I Grade II itself and for further promotion to higher grades by framing rules which were discriminatory

facts.text: Re-organisation scheme launched before Sept. 29, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Before Sept. 29, 1944, when the re-organisation scheme was launched, the companyditions of service and pay-scales of Income tax officers were different

facts.text: Letter dated 23-3-43 decided to designate existing Asstt. Income Tax officers as Income tax officers, Grade II.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated 23-3-43, it was decided that pending the companystitution of Class I and Class II Service of Income tax officers, the latter of which will include also officers hitherto called Asstt. Income Tax officers, the existing grade of Asstt.

facts.text: Re-organisation scheme formulated in letter dated 29-9-44.

anchor.surface_text: This re-organisation scheme was formulated in a letter dated 29-9-44 from the Government of India, addressed to all Commissioners of income tax.

facts.text: Recruitment to Income tax officers Grade II Class I: 80% direct via Indian Audit and Accounts exam, 20% promotion from Grade III.

anchor.surface_text: Recruitment to Grade II will be made partly by promotion and partly by direct recruitment. 80 per cent of the vacancies arising in this Grade will be filled by direct recruitment via the Indian Audit and Accounts and Allied Services Examination. The re- maining 20 per cent of vacancies will be filled by promotion

facts.text: Selections also from existing Grade I Income tax officers Class II Service.

anchor.surface_text: As we read this scheme, it is quite clear that the intention was number to companyfine recruitment to the Service through these sources because from Para 3 General, which we have reproduced above, it is quite evident that selections were to be made also from the existing Grade I Income tax officers Class II Service.

facts.text: Respondents 31 to 39 appointed as I.T.Os. Class 1, grade II in 1945.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention here that respondents 31 to 39 were appointed as I.T.0s. Class 1, grade II in 1945, respondents II and 25 in 1946

facts.text: Respondents 11 and 25 appointed in 1946, respondent 25 original date 1-6-1947.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention here that respondents 31 to 39 were appointed as I.T.0s. Class 1, grade II in 1945, respondents II and 25 in 1946, but the original date of appointment of respondent No. 25 is 1-6-1947.

facts.text: All petitioners appointed I.T.Os Class I Grade II in 1946 or 1947.

anchor.surface_text: All the petitioners were either appointed I.T.Os Class I Grade II in 1946 or 1947.

facts.text: Respondents 6 to 10, 26, 27 and 28 appointed in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 6 to 10, 26, 27 and 28 were appointed in 1947.

facts.text: Petitioners completed probationary periods in 1949 and confirmed as I.T.Os Class 1, Grade II in 1949 and 1950, except petitioner No. 9 on 22-12-1951.

anchor.surface_text: To resume the narrative, the petitioners companypleted their probationary periods on different dates in 1949 and were companyfirmed as I.T.Os Class 1, Grade II in 1949 and 1950, except petitioner No. 9 Shri D. N. Pande, who was companyfirmed on 22-12-1951.

facts.text: Most respondents confirmed on various dates in 1946, 1947, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Most of the respondents had already been companyfirmed on various dates in 1946, 1947 and 1948.

facts.text: On 29-4-1949 Departmental Promotion Committee meeting agreed promotions from 1st August 1948 for respondents 12-24,29,30.

anchor.surface_text: On 29-4-1949 a meeting of the Departmental Promotion Committee took place and the Committee agreed that promotions to Income tax officers Class I Service, of officers recruited in 1944 on the results of the I.A. A.S. and Allied Services examination held in 1943, and on other bases, should be given effect to from the 1st August 1948. This decision affected respondents Nos. 12 to 24, 29 and 30.

facts.text: Seniority Rules framed on 9-9-1949, seniority list as on 1st Jan. 1950 circulated on 24-1-1950.

anchor.surface_text: On 9-9-1949 Seniority Rules were framed and a seniority list of Class 1, Grade II, Income tax officers, as on the 1st Jan. 1950, was drawn up and circulated by a letter dated 24-1-1950.

facts.text: On 18-10-1951 Government modified quota to 66-2/3% direct recruitment, 33-1/3% promotion.

anchor.surface_text: On 18-10-1951, the Government decided on the recommendations of the U.P.S.C. and in modification of para 2 d  of the Finance Department  Central Revenues  letter dated 29-9- 1944, that for a period of five years in the first instance, 66-2/3 of the vacancies in Class T,Grade II, will, be filled by direct recruit-

facts.text: All petitioners promoted as I.T.0s. Class 1, Grade 1 and confirmed on 1-1-1952.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-1-1952 all the petitioners were promoted as I.T.0s. Class 1, Grade 1, and companyfirmed also as such on the same date.

facts.text: Revised seniority list issued on 1-8-53.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-8-53, a revised seniority list was issued.

facts.text: Petitioners promoted as Asstt. Commissioners in 1955 and 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 and 1956, the petitioners were promoted as Asstt. Commissioners on different dates.

facts.text: Jaisinghani filed Writ Petition in High Court on 25-4-62, judgment on 11-3-64, appeal to SC decided 22-2-67.

anchor.surface_text: On 25-4-62 Jaisinghani filed a Writ Petition in the High Court and the High Court delivered its judgment on 11-3-64. Against this decision Jaisinghani filed an appeal to this Court. A writ petition was filed by Joshi in the Supreme Court and this Court delivered its judgment in Jaisinghanis Appeal and Joshis Writ Petition on 22-2-67

facts.text: Present Writ Petition filed in July 1967.

anchor.surface_text: and the present Writ Petition was filed in July 1967.

facts.text: Court holds appointments pre-Constitution cannot be challenged under Arts. 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the petitioners cannot companyplain of the breach of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution in respect of acts done before the Constitution came into force. These acts in this case were  1  appointments of the respondents to Income Tax officers Class I, Grade II Service

facts.text: Petition dismissed due to gross delay.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioners says that this Court has numberdiscretion and cannot dismiss the petition under Art. 32 on the ground that it has been brought after inordinate delay.

facts.text: In Jaisinghani case, order does not affect Class II officers permanently appointed as Assistant Commissioners.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, in Jaisinghanis case 1 , this Court said that the order in that case will number affect such Class II officers who have been appointed permanently as Assistant Commissioners of Income Tax.

facts.text: Present petition brought about 15 years after 1952 Seniority Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The ground being that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution has been brought about 15 years after the 1952 Rules were promulgated and effect given to them in the Seniority List prepared on August 1, 1953.

issues.text: Whether the appointments of respondents 6 to 39 were irregular and illegal being outside the quota and discriminatory in seniority

anchor.surface_text: The Government in breach of the rules governing the service of Income tax officers Class 1, grade II, appointed respondents 6 to 39. Their initial, appointments were irregular and illegal being outside the quota prescribed by Government for regulating recruitment to the service. Not only were they thus illegally absorbed into service but were also given preferential treatment in the matter of seniority

issues.text: Whether this Court has discretion to dismiss a petition under Art. 32 on the ground of inordinate delay

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioners says that this Court has no discretion and cannot dismiss the petition under Art. 32 on the ground that it has been brought after inordinate delay. We are unable to accept this contention.

issues.text: Whether changes in the 1952 Seniority Rules and List violate Arts. 14 and 16

anchor.surface_text: The position is, however, different in so far as changes were made in the Seniority List as a result of change in the 1952 Seniority Rules. These changes were post-constitution and if they are hit by Art. 14 and Art. 16 of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether the decision in 1952 regarding backdating the Departmental Promotion Committee meeting was arbitrary

anchor.surface_text: It is contended before us that this decision was arbitrary and not warranted by any rules or principles. It is further contended that the decision was made in 1952 and therefore it is liable to be challenged in a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. This Court by majority in Ms. Tilokchand Moti Chands case 1 held that delay can be fatal in certain circumstances.

arguments.claim: Recruitment under scheme not confined to direct recruits and promotions from Grade III; includes selections from existing Grade I Class II

anchor.surface_text: As we read this scheme, it is quite clear that the intention was not to confine recruitment to the Service through these sources because from Para 3 General... selections were to be made also from the existing Grade I Income tax officers Class II Service.

arguments.claim: 1952 Seniority Rules changes post-Constitution but challenge barred by 15-year delay

anchor.surface_text: The position is, however, different in so far as changes were made in the Seniority List as a result of change in the 1952 Seniority Rules. ... this petition under Art. 32 ... brought about 15 years after the 1952 Rules

holdings.text: Petitioners cannot complain of the breach of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution in respect of acts done before the Constitution came into force, including appointments of respondents to Income Tax officers Class I Grade II Service, Seniority List as on 1-1-1950, and Seniority Rules of 1949 and 1950 up to January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the petitioners cannot complain of the breach of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution in respect of acts done before the Constitution came into force. These acts in this case were (1) appointments of the respondents to Income Tax officers Class I, Grade II Service (2) Seniority List as existing on 1-1-1950 and (3) the Seniority Rules of 1949 and 1950, in so far as they had effect up to January 26, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution has no retrospective operation as settled law; cites Pannalal Binjrai, Keshavan Madhava Menon; distinguishes Shanti Sarup as inapplicable to pre-Constitution appointments and seniority fixed by then-applicable rules.

holdings.text: Court has discretion to dismiss petition under Art. 32 on ground of inordinate delay without reasonable explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioners says that this Court has no discretion and cannot dismiss the petition under Art. 32 on the ground that it has been brought after inordinate delay. We are unable to accept this contention. This Court by majority in Ms. Tilokchand Moti Chands case held that delay can be fatal in certain circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's contention; cites Tilokchand Moti Chand and Laxmanappa Hanumantappa; highest court must administer justice per equity, not entertain stale demands.

holdings.text: Petition under Art. 32 barred by gross and inordinate delay of about 15 years after 1952 Seniority Rules and list of 1-8-1953, even for post-Constitution changes.

anchor.surface_text: The position is, however, different in so far as changes were made in the Seniority List as a result of change in the 1952 Seniority Rules. These changes were post-constitution... The ground being that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution has been brought about 15 years after the 1952 Rules were promulgated and effect given to them in the Seniority List prepared on August 1, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unjust to disturb accrued rights after years; representations have limit; facts known earlier than claimed; cites no relief for stale claims.

holdings.text: Recruitment to Income tax officers Class I Grade II under 29-9-1944 scheme not confined to direct recruitment via examination and promotion from Grade III Class II; includes selections from existing Grade I Income tax officers Class II Service.

anchor.surface_text: We may at this stage consider the question mooted at the Bar whether recruitment to the Service under the scheme was to be confined only to direct recruitment through the Examination and promotion from Grade I Class II service. As we read this scheme, it is quite clear that the intention was not to confine recruitment to the Service through these sources because from Para 3 General, which we have reproduced above, it is quite evident that selections were to be made also from the existing Grade I Income tax officers Class II Service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of scheme Para 3 General shows selections from existing Grade I Class II outside Para 2d quota; counter-affidavit correct on this.

holdings.text: Cannot declare appointments of respondents invalid at this time.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that apart from the above limited concession, we cannot at this time declare that the appointments were invalid in any respect. Assuming that these appointments were made contrary to statutory Rules, the petitioners are incompetent to challenge the validity of these appointments for various reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-Constitution; inordinate delay; acquired rights; Jaisinghani protects permanent Asst Commissioners.

holdings.text: Decision on backdating Departmental Promotion Committee not taken in 1952 but earlier; seniority fixed on that basis.

anchor.surface_text: On the material on record it is not possible to say that this decision was actually taken in 1952 and not on 29-4-49 or thereabout when The Departmental Promotion Committee met and the list was prepared on 24th January 1950. The fact is that the seniority of the respondents (Srl. Nos. 72 to 86) seems to have been fixed on the basis that the Departmental Promotion Committee meeting took place on 6-9-1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Material shows decision reflected in 1950 list; anyway barred by delay.

precedents.cited_proposition: observations in Shanti Sarup were not intended to lay down an unqualified proposition that even if a citizen was deprived of his fundamental rights by a valid scheme framed under a valid law at a time when the Constitution was not in force, the mere fact that such a scheme would continue to operate even after 26th January 1950 would expose it to challenge under Art. 13

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the petitioners cannot complain of the breach of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution in respect of acts done before the Constitution came into force. These acts in this case were (1) appointments of the respondents to Income Tax officers Class I, Grade II Service (2) Seniority List as existing on 1-1-1950 and (3) the Seniority Rules of 1949 and 1950, in so far as they had effect up to January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioners says that this Court has no discretion and cannot dismiss the petition under Art. 32 on the ground that it has been brought after inordinate delay. We are unable to accept this contention. This Court by majority in Ms. Tilokchand Moti Chands case held that delay can be fatal in certain circumstances.

It seems to us that there is force in the preliminary points raised by the Attorney General, and it is number necessary to decide the various points raised by the petitioners. It is settled law that the Constitution has numberretrospect
Art. 32. In view of this decision it has to be held that the petition under Art. 32 is number maintainable in the, situation that has arisen and that

anchor.surface_text: The position is, however, different in so far as changes were made in the Seniority List as a result of change in the 1952 Seniority Rules. These changes were post-constitution... The ground being that this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution has been brought about 15 years after the 1952 Rules were promulgated and effect given to them in the Seniority List prepared on August 1, 1953.

It seems to us that there is force in the preliminary points raised by the Attorney General, and it is number necessary to decide the various points raised by the petitioners. It is settled law that the Constitution has numberretrospect

We may at this stage consider the question mooted at the Bar whether recruitment to the Service under the scheme was to be confined only to direct recruitment through the Examination and promotion from Grade I Class II service. As we read this scheme, it is quite clear that the intention was not to confine recruitment to the Service through these sources because from Para 3 General, which we have reproduced above, it is quite evident that selections were to be made also from the existing Grade I Income tax officers Class II Service.

It seems to us that there is force in the preliminary points raised by the Attorney General, and it is number necessary to decide the various points raised by the petitioners. It is settled law that the Constitution has numberretrospect

anchor.surface_text: On the material on record it is not possible to say that this decision was actually taken in 1952 and not on 29-4-49 or thereabout when The Departmental Promotion Committee met and the list was prepared on 24th January 1950. The fact is that the seniority of the respondents (Srl. Nos. 72 to 86) seems to have been fixed on the basis that the Departmental Promotion Committee meeting took place on 6-9-1948.
